title: Sir Elton John's praise of Taron Egerton is so pure
text:
These two (Picture: WireImage)

Sir Elton John thinks the world of actor Taron Egerton, and, honestly, get you someone who supports you in this way.

The 72-year-old singer has heaped praise on Taron, who played him in the Rocketman biopic, as the pair cruised towards awards season with tinted glasses over their eyes.

Speaking about the close bond he has developed with Taron, 29, Elton went so far as to dub the Welsh star ‘family’.

And isn’t that sweet?

Asked if he’d offer Taron any career advice, Elton explained he really didn’t think the lad needed it ‘because he seems to have it figured out for himself’.

Taron played Elton in Rocketman (Picture: Rex Features)

Saying he saw Taron as ‘part of my family’, Elton continued to Entertainment Tonight: ‘He’s much more happy within himself and I think that’s the truth.’

The feeling is mutual as Taron was similarly fond of the chart-topping musician, as he admitted it’s ‘been a very surreal process getting to know him’.

‘He doesn’t want me to be constantly looking at him like he’s God,’ Taron said.

‘He wants me to look at him like he’s my friend, which he is.’

Oh lordy we ship these two. Give them all the Oscars now.

It comes after Elton recently came under fire for the Lion King remake, citing the latest reboot as ‘disappointing’.

The star – who composed and performed songs for the original animated film in 1994 – was of the belief Disney ‘messed the music up’ with the recent movie, which featured the likes of Beyonce and OG Mufasa James Earl Jones.

Ouch.

He said: ‘The new version of The Lion King was a huge disappointment to me, because I believe they messed the music up.

‘Music was so much a part of the original and the music in the current film didn’t have the same impact. The magic and joy were lost.’

In response, Billy Eichner – who voice Timon alongside Seth Rogen’s Pumbaa – simply took to Twitter to share an image of the Gnomeo And Juliet soundtrack, which Elton worked on, and captioned it: ‘What a beautiful score.’
